title: Fez: More than 400 children with disabilities benefit from a multidisciplinary medical caravan
text:
Organized at⁣ the initiative of the Regional Academy of Education and Training (AREF) of Fez-Meknes, in partnership with the Association Return of Hope to Cochlear⁤ Implant Holders (AREPIC), this caravan targeted⁤ children cochlear implant recipients and their guardians from inclusive ‍schools in the⁤ region.
This humanitarian initiative, hosted by the Abdellatif Laâbi primary school, aims ‌to prepare the medical files of children with cochlear implants in order ‌to​ facilitate⁢ their integration into ordinary schools as well as ⁤their access to a series​ of educational programs.
This caravan, which ⁤mobilized 20 medical and paramedical⁢ executives and associative⁣ actors,⁢ included several specialties, notably hearing correction, physiotherapy, psychotherapy, psychomotor skills , ​sensorimotor therapy, genetic medicine and medical diagnosis.
This operation also included advice and guidance sessions for the benefit of families, in particular direct meetings with children with cochlear implants and their parents, during which the latter were made aware of the need to strengthen communication with children at home, to ensure good ⁢linguistic preparation and to ensure‌ that children wear their cochlear implants throughout the day and only remove them when going to sleep.
Cultural and entertainment activities⁣ for children benefiting from the caravan​ were also organized in parallel with the caravan, on the occasion⁢ of the 49th anniversary of ⁣the Green March.
In a statement to MAP, the head of the inclusive education department at AREF Fez-Meknes, Halim Hicham, indicated that ‍this caravan is part of the launch of the⁤ regional program of medical caravans organized by the Academy in partnership with AREPIC, targeting a group of students educated in inclusive ⁣education establishments.
This initiative aims in particular to provide these students with medical records which will facilitate their learning, as well as to help them adapt to the different activities of school life,‌ continuous assessment activities and certifying exams, he said. added.
For her part, the president⁣ of AREPIC, Nezha Sehaki, affirmed that this medical caravan, which includes the participation of ‍a number of medical specialists from different⁣ disciplines, aims to facilitate the harmonious‍ integration ⁢of children with ‍cochlear implants. in ⁤mainstream educational establishments.
“The association cares for children ‍with cochlear implants, who benefit from a ⁤range⁢ of services ⁣including speech therapy, specialist education, psychomotor skills and other⁤ parallel activities,” she added .
For her ‍part, the ‌director of the association, Fatima Zahra ‌Mechouahi, indicated that AREPIC, created​ in 2013, works to take care of children with cochlear implants, specifying that for⁣ the current‌ academic year, Some 290 girls and boys are taken care of, including 135 children integrated into ordinary establishments.
Time.news Editor: Welcome⁣ to our interview today! We have ‌the pleasure of speaking ‍with Dr. Amina El Ghazali, an expert in audiology and a leading‌ advocate for ‌children‌ with hearing impairments. Dr.⁣ El Ghazali, thank you so much for joining us.
Dr. Amina El ⁣Ghazali: Thank you for having me! It’s a pleasure to be here and discuss⁣ such ‍an important initiative.
Editor: Let’s dive right in. I understand you recently ⁤participated in the caravan organized by the Regional Academy of Education ​and Training in Fez-Meknes. What were the main goals of ‌this initiative?
Dr. El Ghazali: ‌ The caravan aimed to provide support for children with cochlear implants and their families, particularly those attending inclusive schools. Our primary goal was to ‌prepare their medical files, which is crucial for their effective integration into mainstream education. Additionally, we wanted to ensure they could⁤ access relevant educational programs that cater to ⁢their unique needs.
Editor: It sounds like ‌a ‌comprehensive approach. Can you ​elaborate on the variety of specialists involved and how they contributed to the initiative’s ‌success?
Dr. El Ghazali: ​Absolutely! The‌ caravan mobilized⁤ a team of 20 professionals, including audiologists, ‍physiotherapists, psychotherapists, and specialists in psychomotor skills and genetic medicine. Each provided specialized services that addressed various aspects of the children’s health and development. For instance, hearing correction experts⁤ assisted with optimizing the use of cochlear implants, while psychologists offered emotional ​support, ensuring that these children are not only physically healthy but also ⁣mentally and emotionally prepared for their educational journeys.
Editor: That’s incredible! Engaging the family is ​key in such scenarios. What kind⁤ of advice and guidance did you ⁤provide to parents during⁤ the caravan?
Dr. El Ghazali: ‍ We held interactive sessions where parents learned the importance of consistent communication ⁢with their children. We⁣ emphasized⁤ linguistic development at home and ​the necessity for children⁣ to wear their cochlear implants throughout the day. We also discussed the significance of creating a supportive‌ and language-rich environment, which is vital for their social and academic success.
Editor: It’s heartening to hear how proactive the‌ initiative is in ‌addressing not just the children’s needs but also the‌ family ⁣dynamics. Were there any specific ‌activities designed to support children during the event?
Dr. ‌El Ghazali: Yes! We organized cultural‍ and entertainment activities to engage the‌ children in a fun and supportive environment. These activities aimed to foster social connections among the children, which is essential ⁢for their overall development. It’s‌ important that they enjoy their time while also benefiting from‌ the initiative.
Editor: This holistic approach makes a significant difference. In your experience, how do you see initiatives⁤ like this impacting the long-term integration of children with cochlear implants in schools?
Dr. El Ghazali: Initiatives⁣ like this are pivotal in breaking down barriers. ‍By ensuring that children with cochlear implants receive the‌ necessary support and preparation, ⁢we greatly enhance​ their chances of thriving in mainstream education. ‍It’s not just about the medical aspect;⁢ it’s about instilling confidence in the children and their families, which leads to a⁤ more inclusive society overall.
Editor: ⁣ That’s a powerful point. Looking ahead, ⁣what more can be done to ‌further support these children and their families?
Dr. El Ghazali: There’s always room for ​improvement. Ongoing training for educators on how to approach and support‌ children‌ with hearing impairments is crucial. ⁣Additionally, more community awareness programs can help demystify cochlear implants and hearing loss . Collaboration​ between healthcare providers, educational institutions, and families will truly pave the way ⁤for these children to succeed.
Editor: Thank you, Dr. El Ghazali, for your insights and for the invaluable work you do. It’s clear that initiatives like this are not just beneficial but​ essential for fostering inclusivity and empowering⁤ children with hearing impairments.
Dr. El Ghazali: Thank‍ you for shining a light on this important topic! I‍ appreciate⁤ the opportunity to share.
